newsitem.title: FRANCE: Oscar-winner Salvatores in nightmare cyber-plunge.
newsitem.headline: Oscar-winner Salvatores in nightmare cyber-plunge.

text.p: Children playing with a computer near a Buddhist temple on the banks of the river Ganges gave Oscar-winning Gabriele Salvatores the spark for "Nirvana", a nightmarish sci-fi plunge into cyber-space.

"I was in India in Benares and I saw the children by the temple. That made me think that the central question of Buddhist philosophy is that the life we lead is not real," the Italian director, 44, said in a beach interview at the Cannes film festival on Monday.

"The same goes for virtual reality, and it will be more and more difficult to establish the difference between reality and non-reality," the director said of his latest movie, which is light years away from the bitter-sweet "Mediterraneo" which won him the Oscar for best foreign film in 1991.

Videogame designer Jimmy (Christophe Lambert), under pressure to meet a Christmas 2005 deadline for his latest creation, sees his life take a turn for the worse when his computer hero Solo (Diego Abbantuono) suddenly rebels at the futility of a role in which he is shot dead again and again after each "Game Over".

In his quest to zap Solo out of cyberspace -- the only relief Jimmy can give him -- the computer wizard goes on the run in a megalopolis carved into ghettos, including an Indian-inspired underground city where religion co-exists with high technology.
Cyber-enthusiasts navigate clandestinely between reality and virtual reality, sometimes having their brains sucked out by the computer network's police in the process.

"You can't change your destiny just like that. If you can't change the game, the only way out is to stop playing. It's suicide, that's true, but it's not really a negative choice," said Salvatores, whose credits include "Marrakesh Express" and "Puerto Escondido".

Special effects and humour feature prominently in the oppressive universe Salvatores took three years to create for "Nirvana", produced by a French firm and distributed by Miramax in the United States.
Locations were scouted in Morocco and India before the team decided to film in the plant of a former Alfa Romeo factory in Milan.
"It's a European film, even if it's a science-fiction movie. If I'd been American, I'm not sure I would have put humour in such a film.
"Humour is my way of seeing things. And there's something comical about seeing characters in a video game trying to rebuild their lives," Salvatores said.
His theme, which he dubs "contamination between man and machine", echoes last year's Cannes shocker "Crash" by David Cronenberg which tracked the sexual highs of perverts obsessed by car crashes.
"It's a very philosophical thriller, which raises many questions but even in this virtual universe, it preserves its European character," said Emmanuelle Seigner, who haunts Lambert in the film.
